revised_title: Prolonged Endplate Depolarization in Anti-Esterase Treated Muscle
tldr: The authors studied the prolonged endplate depolarization in anti-esterase treated muscle and found that it is mainly due to the accumulation of acetylcholine residue during nerve stimulation. They used intracellular recording of endplate potential and current in glycerol-pretreated frog sartorius muscle and concluded that the post-tetanic depolarization is accompanied by membrane fluctuations resembling typical 'acetylcholine noise'. This indicates that the prolonged depolarization arises from the continued action of a residue of acetylcholine.
